metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-eddy covariance system-40m tower, 2016)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of 40m tower vortex correlator on January 1, 2016, solstice, 2016, December 31, 2016.The station is located in east garden town, huailai county, hebei province.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7923E, 40.3574N, and the altitude is 480m.The acquisition frequency of vortex correlativity instrument is 10Hz, the frame height is 3.5m, the ultrasonic direction is due to the north, and the distance between the ultrasonic anemometer (CSAT3) and the CO2/H2O analyzer (EC150) is 0cm.

The released data is the 30-minute data obtained from the post-processing of the original collected 10Hz data with Eddypro software. The main steps of the processing include: outfield value elimination, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction and density (WPL) correction.Quality assessment for each intercompared to at the same time, mainly is the atmospheric stability (Δ st) and turbulent characteristics of similarity (ITC) test.The 30min pass value output after processing was also screened :(1) the data when the instrument was wrong was removed;(2) data of 1h before and after precipitation were excluded;(3) the missing rate of 10Hz original data is more than 10% every 30min;(4) the observed data of weak turbulence at night were excluded (u* less than 0.1m/s).The average period of observation data was 30 minutes, 48 data a day, and the missing data was marked as -6999.There are many negative values of water vapor density measured by EC150 in winter, filled with -6999.

The observation data released by vortex correlator include:Date/Time for the Date/Time, wind Wdir (°), Wnd horizontal wind speed (m/s), standard deviation Std_Uy lateral wind speed (m/s), ultrasonic virtual temperature Tv (K), the water vapor density H2O (g/m3), carbon dioxide concentration CO2 (mg/m3), friction velocity Ustar) (m/s), the length of cloth hoff, sensible heat flux Hs (W/m2), latent heat flux LE (W/m2), carbon dioxide flux Fc (mg/(m2s)), the quality of the sensible heat flux identifier QA_Hs, the quality of the latent heat flux identifier QA_LE.The quality of the sensible heat and latent heat, carbon dioxide flux identification is divided into three (quality id 0: (Δ st < 30, the ITC < 30);1: (Δ st < 100, ITC < 100);The rest are 2).The meaning of data time, such as 0:30 represents the average between 0:00 and 0:30;The data is stored in *.xls format.The data was missing during the period from May 26 to May 29 due to instrument calibration.

Guo et al, 2020 is used for site introduction and Liu et al, 2013 for data processing

File naming method: **** station-####-xx tower-yyyy, where **** * represents the site name, #### # represents the site type, xx represents the tower height (meters), yyyy represents the data observation year
Data usage: this data is tabular data, which can be opened and viewed by WPS, Ecxel and other software

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, affecting the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and influencing the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness of only tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), compared to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS can better match the pixel scale of satellite imagery and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thus optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the observed atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, winter wheat (corn) accounts for approximately 45% of the area, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation in the source area can reach a height of 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for determining the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two judgment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'eddy covariance system' in the context of measuring surface fluxes?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system (EC) is recognized internationally as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes, which include heat and water vapor exchanges between the land and atmosphere. This method, however, has a limited observation scale, typically representing areas only a few tens to hundreds of meters in size.

Definition.Question: What does 'aerodynamic roughness length' indicate in the context of remote sensing and land surface models?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a parameter critical for estimating surface fluxes in remote sensing algorithms and land surface models. It represents the height at which wind speed extrapolated from the logarithmic wind profile reaches zero and varies significantly across different surfaces, reflecting the roughness characteristics and influencing turbulence and surface-atmosphere exchange processes.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using an eddy covariance system at a fixed station compare to those using a large aperture scintillometer in terms of spatial and temporal scale?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system is recognized as a reliable method for surface flux observation but operates on a smaller spatial scale of tens to hundreds of meters. In contrast, the large aperture scintillometer can measure fluxes over a much larger area, from 500 meters to 10 kilometers, making it more suitable for regional scale observations. Temporally, eddy covariance provides high-frequency data, whereas LAS provides data that can be better matched to satellite pixel and weather model grid scales.

Comparison.Question: In terms of challenges faced during data collection, how does the applicability of Monin-Obukhov similarity theory differ between eddy covariance and large aperture scintillometer methods?
Comparison.Answer: For eddy covariance systems, the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory is used to calculate parameters like friction velocity and Obukhov length, with the main challenge being the small spatial representativeness and the influence of local heterogeneities. For large aperture scintillometers, the applicability of the theory is influenced by factors such as large-scale eddies and atmospheric stability conditions, with additional challenges arising from the need for accurate estimates of temperature structure parameters. Both methods find it difficult to completely conform to the ideal assumptions of the theory, particularly under heterogeneous terrain and varying atmospheric conditions.

Interpretation.Question: How can the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces and its directional characteristics be inferred from observational data?
Interpretation.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces can be inferred by calculating individual z0m over each surface component using the characteristic parameters of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. These values are then aggregated using a footprint weighting method, allowing for the analysis of the directional characteristics of z0m based on the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements along different wind directions.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the differences between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations in measuring surface fluxes?
Interpretation.Answer: Insights can be drawn by analyzing the daily and monthly variations of sensible heat flux from LAS data and comparing them with eddy covariance system observations. The differences can be further studied using a footprint model and exploring the energy balance discrepancies of the eddy covariance system, considering factors such as LAS beam height, wind speed sensitivity, and zero-plane displacement height.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of data processing techniques for eddy covariance systems in surface flux observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of data processing techniques for eddy covariance systems is influenced by the need to correct raw data for errors such as wild value removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. These steps are crucial to ensure the quality and accuracy of surface flux data, as well as to evaluate the stability and similarity characteristics of turbulence.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) challenging to determine for local or regional scales using station observations alone?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Determining aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for local or regional scales using only station observations is challenging because z0m varies significantly across different surfaces and is affected by the structure and spacing of roughness elements. The complexity of surface heterogeneity and the need for parameterizations based on land surface properties make it difficult to extrapolate z0m from point measurements to larger areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for surface flux measurement?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to LAS data arises from variations in surface cover, flatness, water heat conditions, and weather conditions, which challenge the assumption of horizontal homogeneity. Additionally, the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics is less studied, necessitating the development of new methods to assess MOST applicability reliably.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the quality of surface flux measurements when using different data post-processing techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different data post-processing techniques, such as Eddypro software for raw data processing, can significantly impact the quality of surface flux measurements by improving data reliability through steps like outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, and density corrections, as well as ensuring data quality through stability and similarity tests.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the availability of more comprehensive data affect the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in land surface models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The availability of more comprehensive data could enhance the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) by providing better insights into the relationship between z0m and land surface properties, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, which would improve model accuracy in representing surface roughness characteristics.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the impact on regional climate model validation if large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data becomes more widely available for surface flux measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: If large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data becomes more widely available, it could significantly improve regional climate model validation by providing surface flux measurements that match the scale of satellite pixels and model grids, thus offering more reliable ground truth for optimizing and verifying remote sensing models and numerical weather prediction models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to explore the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations over different land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Exploring the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations is essential because it helps assess the reliability of surface flux measurements over heterogeneous surfaces. Since LAS can measure fluxes on a larger scale that matches satellite pixel scales and numerical models, validating MOST ensures that these measurements can be used to optimize and verify remote sensing models and climate simulations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure quality and accuracy before it is published?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involved in processing eddy covariance data typically include outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is performed, primarily testing atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data are further filtered by removing data during instrument errors, rainfall, high missing rates, and weak nighttime turbulence.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one utilize the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in conjunction with large aperture scintillometer data to assess surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To utilize the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory with large aperture scintillometer data, it is important to first process data from eddy covariance and scintillometer systems. This involves analyzing the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter and related meteorological data. The temperature structure parameter's universal stability function is used to derive regional average sensible heat flux. The process also includes establishing and validating new applicability judgment methods, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, to account for the heterogeneity of the landscape.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches can be adopted to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces using experimental data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methodological approaches to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) involve using experimental data to compute individual z0m over each surface component by considering roughness element characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index. The z0m over the entire experimental field is then aggregated using the footprint weighting method. This entails analyzing directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces and relating z0m to roughness element characteristic factors for parameterization, to aid in model parameterizations.

Enablement.Question: What specific data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw turbulent data into reliable 30-minute average values for surface flux measurements?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction are used to transform raw turbulent data into reliable 30-minute average values.

Enablement.Question: How does the implementation of quality control measures enable the accurate assessment of flux measurements in eddy covariance systems?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control measures, including the evaluation of atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, help in assessing the quality of flux measurements by categorizing them into different quality levels, ensuring data reliability.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do environmental and equipment conditions enable the selection of appropriate data filtering criteria for eddy covariance data collection?
Enablement.Answer: Environmental conditions like precipitation and equipment conditions such as instrument errors are used to set data filtering criteria, such as excluding data collected around rainfall events and removing data with more than 10% missing in each 30-minute interval.

Expectation.Question: Why might the eddy-covariance system be expected to face challenges in representing larger spatial scales despite being recognized as a reliable method for surface flux observation?
Expectation.Answer: The eddy-covariance system is known for its reliability in measuring surface fluxes, but it has a limited spatial scale representation, typically ranging from tens to a few hundred meters. This limitation arises because the system's measurements are confined to smaller areas where turbulence can be directly captured, making it challenging to extrapolate these observations to larger, regional scales without additional modeling or data integration methods.

Expectation.Question: What factors could potentially influence the expected accuracy and reliability of the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) estimation using traditional wind profile measurements?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy and reliability of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) estimation can be influenced by the variability in surface characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index, as these affect wind turbulence. Additionally, the traditional Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory requires precise wind profile measurements, which can be challenging to obtain across different land surface types and scales, particularly when relying solely on station observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) face challenges in low wind speed and very stable conditions during nighttime measurements, and what could be an expected approach to address this issue?
Expectation.Answer: The LAS system may encounter convergence issues in calculating sensible heat flux (HLAS) during low wind speed and very stable conditions at night. This is because the universal stability function fT used in the calculations lacks consensus in its form, and the iterative process may not converge under these conditions. An expected approach to address this issue could involve setting specific stability thresholds or enhancing the model with additional parameters to ensure reliable calculations in such scenarios.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges of implementing the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in the analysis of surface flux data over agricultural fields with varying crop cover?
Judgmental.Answer: Implementing MOST in agricultural fields with varying crop cover is challenging due to the heterogeneity in vegetation height and land cover, which can affect the assumptions of uniformity and stability in MOST. The variability in surface roughness and thermal properties of different crops may lead to discrepancies in data interpretation and require adaptation or calibration of the theory to local conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) can be accurately estimated over heterogeneous surfaces using data from multiple years and different land covers.
Assertion.Answer: Based on the Xiaotangshan Experiment, z0m was calculated over several land surfaces using characteristic parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index. An analytical footprint model was used to analyze directional characteristics, and z0m for the entire field was aggregated using the footprint weighting method.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the parameters for surface flux measurements are chosen when using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) compared to other methods.
Assertion.Answer: For LAS data, parameters like beam height and wind speed are crucial in measuring sensible heat flux. The zero-plane displacement height is significant unless the beam height is much larger. Although air temperature, air pressure, and aerodynamic roughness length are less sensitive, the Bowen ratio must be accurately determined over wet surfaces.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data collection methodologies that could complement eddy covariance systems for more extensive surface flux measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) could be a complementary method to expand the spatial scale of surface flux measurements, as it can measure fluxes over a larger area compared to eddy covariance systems, which have a smaller spatial representativeness.
